verses.text: Behold, a day is coming for the LORD, when your plunder will be divided in your midst.
verses.comment: Zechariah prophesies a future day of the LORD, an eschatological theme common throughout the prophets. The mention of plunder recalling judgment, but also the sovereignty of God even in times of calamity.

verses.text: For I will gather all the nations against Jerusalem to battle. The city will be captured, the houses plundered and the women raped. Half of the city will go into exile, but the rest of the people will not be cut off from the city.
verses.comment: The imagery of nations gathering against Jerusalem anticipates Armageddon and final tribulation. The remnant remaining is a recurring biblical theme, emphasizing God's mercy amidst judgment (Isaiah 10:20-22).

verses.text: Then the LORD will go out and fight against those nations, as when he fights on a day of battle.
verses.comment: This verse shows direct divine intervention, linking back to God fighting for Israel in Exodus. The language hints at the LORD's ultimate sovereignty and His role as a divine warrior.

verses.text: On that day his feet will stand on the Mount of Olives, which lies before Jerusalem on the east. The Mount of Olives will be split in two from east to west by a very great valley, so that half of the mountain will move north and half south.
verses.comment: The Mount of Olives has strong messianic associations, as echoed in the New Testament with Jesus' ascension (Acts 1:11-12). The splitting of the mountain suggests a dramatic intervention, a symbol of God's power to remake creation.

verses.text: You will flee by the valley of my mountains, for the valley between the mountains will reach to Azal. You will flee just as you fled from the earthquake in the days of Uzziah king of Judah. Then the LORD my God will come, and all the holy ones with him.
verses.comment: The holy ones (often interpreted as angels or saints) accompany the LORD, mirroring apocalyptic scenes in the New Testament (1 Thess. 4:16). Early Christian writers saw this as foreshadowing the second coming.

verses.text: On that day there will be no light; the bright ones will freeze.
verses.comment: The disruption of cosmic order—sun, moon, stars—often symbolizes the coming Day of the LORD, both as judgment and restoration (see also Joel 2:31; Matthew 24:29).

verses.text: It will be a unique day, known to the LORD, not day and not night, but at evening time there will be light.
verses.comment: This verse points to a time outside normal human reckoning—an eternal day that God alone knows. The promise of light at evening has echoes in Christian eschatology regarding eternal life and unending light.

verses.text: On that day living waters will flow out from Jerusalem, half to the eastern sea and half to the western sea. It will be so in summer and in winter.
verses.comment: Living water from Jerusalem is a powerful image of spiritual renewal, connecting to Ezekiel's vision and to Jesus' claim to provide living water (John 4:10-14). This prefigures sacramental life flowing from the center of God's people.

verses.text: And the LORD will be king over all the earth. On that day the LORD will be one, and his name one.
verses.comment: These words recall the Shema (Deut. 6:4), underscoring God's ultimate unity and kingship. This envisions a universal recognition and worship of the One True God, later realized spiritually in the worldwide spread of the faith.

verses.text: The whole land will be turned into a plain from Geba to Rimmon south of Jerusalem. But Jerusalem will be lifted up and remain in its place, from the Gate of Benjamin to the site of the First Gate, to the Corner Gate, and from the Tower of Hananel to the king’s winepresses.
verses.comment: The lifting up of Jerusalem while the land is flattened may symbolize spiritual exaltation of God's city, foreshadowing the elevation of the people of God in the age to come.

verses.text: And people will dwell in it, and there will be no more curse. Jerusalem will dwell securely.
verses.comment: New Jerusalem's security and freedom from curse is echoed in Revelation's vision of the new creation. The prophetic hope is both fulfilled spiritually in the church and ultimately in the heavenly city.

verses.text: And this will be the plague with which the LORD will strike all the peoples who fought against Jerusalem: their flesh will rot while they stand on their feet, their eyes will rot in their sockets, and their tongues will rot in their mouths.
verses.comment: Grim imagery of judgment recalls similar scenes in Isaiah and Revelation. This emphasizes God's final justice against those opposed to His holy city.

verses.text: On that day a great panic from the LORD will fall on them, so each one will seize the hand of another, and they will raise their hands against one another.
verses.comment: Divine panic causing confusion among the enemies is a recurring motif, as seen at other points in biblical history. This further shows how God can overturn the plans of the nations.

verses.text: Even Judah will fight at Jerusalem, and the wealth of all the surrounding nations will be gathered, gold, silver, and garments in great abundance.
verses.comment: This verse draws on the pattern of Israel's history, where after deliverance the people receive the riches of their adversaries, suggesting the vindication and enrichment of the faithful.

verses.text: And just like this plague, so will be the plague on the horse, mule, camel, donkey, and all the animals that shall be in those camps—this plague will come upon them.
verses.comment: Not only people but also animals suffer in this judgment, reminiscent of the plagues of Egypt. This underlines the totality of divine judgment.

verses.text: Then everyone who is left of all the nations that came against Jerusalem shall go up year after year to worship the King, the LORD of hosts, and to celebrate the Feast of Booths.
verses.comment: This points to the universal worship of the LORD, with a pilgrimage motif. The Feast of Booths (Tabernacles) celebrates God's presence among His people, which finds a fuller realization as peoples from all nations are called to worship Him in unity.

verses.text: But if any of the families of the earth do not go up to Jerusalem to worship the King, the LORD of hosts, there will be no rain upon them.
verses.comment: Participation in worship is directly tied to blessing (rain), echoing covenant curses and blessings in Deuteronomy. Obedience and worship are shown to be necessary for spiritual fruitfulness.

verses.text: If the family of Egypt does not go up and enter in, then upon them there shall be no rain; there shall be the plague with which the LORD strikes the nations that do not go up to celebrate the Feast of Booths.
verses.comment: Egypt, once an archetypal enemy of God's people, is included as a possible worshiper but also threatened with judgment if unrepentant. The invitation to worship is universal, but so is the accountability to it.

verses.text: This shall be the punishment of Egypt and the punishment of all the nations that do not go up to celebrate the Feast of Booths.
verses.comment: The punishment for refusing to worship underscores God's desire for all nations to come to His presence, which is fulfilled in the worldwide call to worship Him 'in spirit and truth' (see John 4:23).

verses.text: On that day there shall be inscribed on the bells of the horses, 'Holy to the LORD.' And the cooking pots in the house of the LORD will be as holy as the bowls before the altar.
verses.comment: The separation between sacred and common is removed; everything is sanctified and set apart. The whole people and their environment are now devoted to divine service, echoing the ideal of a kingdom of priests.

verses.text: Every pot in Jerusalem and in Judah will be holy to the LORD of hosts, so that all who offer sacrifice may come and take them and boil the flesh of the sacrifice in them. And there shall no longer be a Canaanite in the house of the LORD of hosts on that day.
verses.comment: Holiness will pervade every aspect of daily life, not just the temple precincts. The exclusion of 'Canaanite' signifies the removal of anything unclean—the full and perfect sanctification of the worshiping community, anticipating the final fulfillment in the new creation and the heavenly Jerusalem.
